 SECTION A: PROJECT DESCRIPTION I. PROJECT DESIGN A. Project Objective and Approach 1. The objective of the project is to assist the Government of Ghana to implement its public enterprise reform and privatization program. 2. The public enterprise reform program will focus on (a) preparing enterprises for divestiture; (b) monitoring the performance of enterprises, and making information available to the Government and the public; (c) a review of government policy for the public enterprise sector, with an increased focus on the management of the Government's portfolio of equity investments, loans, and guarantees; (d) policy and regulatory reform in a number of key sectors in which SOEs are dominant - aviation, cocoa and petroleum; and (e) building capacity within the Ministry of Finance and State Enterprises Commission (SEC). 3. The privatization program will focus on (a) acceleration of the divestiture program using newly-approved procedures; (b) contracting out the sale of enterprises to private firms; (c) arrangements to address labor redundancies caused by divestiture; (d) arrangements to promote the participation of Ghanaians in the investment opportunities created by divestiture; (e) implementation of a public information and communications strategy, including periodic impact assessments with the participation of key stakeholders; and (f) building capacity within the Divestiture Implementation Committee (DIC). 4. The project design reflects the fact that it is not possible to predict with certainty the implementation of a complex, multi-sectoral program, which impacts upon political and social as well as economic processes, over a five year period. Within the framework of the Government's expressed commitment to the program and the broad public and stakeholder support which exists at present, the project has been designed to provide the flexibility needed to adapt to needs which will vary from sector to sector and circumstances which will change over time. It would also adapt to the outcome of the processes and reviews designed into the project, such as the public information and communications strategy; periodic impact assessments; and policy reviews on how to manage labor redundancies, participation by local investors, the future development of the SOE sector, and the new sector policies in the aviation, cocoa and petroleum sectors. This would give rise to the need for enhanced project supervision. The mid-term review assumes increased importance in this environment, and will be used to review experience in the first two years of implementation and specify at that time, rather than during project preparation, the details of the components of the overall program to be supported during the second half of the project. B. Cofinancing 5. The British ODA is providing technical assistance to the value of $2.6million equivalent to the DIC through the end of 1997. The European Union is expected to provide up to $5.6 million equivalent to assist with retraining as part of a program to address the issue of labor redundancies created by divestiture. The Government will provide around US$ 1.6 million equivalent towards operating costs of the DIC, SEC and the Project Coordination Unit within the
 2 Ministry of Finance. Proceeds from the sale of enterprises will be used to finance payments to creditors, workers' redundancy payments, and success fees to private firms appointed by DIC to privatize enterprises. As part of the mid-term review. the Government and IDA would examine whether a revolving fund could be established using a portion of the sale proceeds to finance all of the remunerations of private firms. C. Project Risks 6. The principal risks are a worsening of the macroeconomic environment, a decline in Government commitment and public support for divestiture, and a lack of project management capacity. 7. The macroeconomic situation and Government commitment will be monitored as part of IDA's overall dialogue with the Government. 8. The Government has reaffirmed its commitment to the program in a Letter of Sector Development Policy dated April 29, 1996. Recent progress on the program under the PETA project is consistent with that level of commitment. As disbursements on the privatization component of the project would be closely linked to progress on selling enterprises, any significant reduction in commitment or implementation capacity would have consequences for the remainder of the program, which would be scaled back, and should not negatively impact reforms or privatizations already concluded. 9. Measures to mitigate the more direct project risks include the public communications program, the implementation of more detailed procedures that will provide the public with greater access to information, the contracting out of the sale of enterprises to private firms, and the establishment of a central focal point in the Ministry of Finance to coordinate project management. The project has been designed with the flexibility to accommodate differing needs and approaches across sectors and over time. In this regard. the mid-term review will be particularly important and will provide the opportunity to re-assess project risks and develop appropriate risk mitigation measures. D. Project Benefits 10. The benefits of the program that the project will support are: (a) An improved climate for private sector investment and development, and thus improved prospects for growth of incomes and employment. This would result from the specific investment opportunities offered by divestiture as well as the strong message that divestiture can send about the role envisaged for the private sector; the greater space created for private sector activity by the reduction of the state's involvement in commercial activities, including the promotion of competition through leveling the playing field; and the improvement in the efficiency and effectiveness of services provided by SOEs, lowering business costs. (b) Improvements in the performance of the public sector. Reductions in subventions to SOEs. including the costs of investment, will free up fiscal resources for higher value uses and contribute to macroeconomic stability. The project will help the Government to
 3 redefine its role in the public enterprise sector to one which has increased focus on policy and regulatory activities. The Government's financial involvement in the sector will evolve to one of managing its investment portfolio of equity holdings. loans and guarantees. The project will also contribute to greater accountability through its support for building capacity for public reporting on the performance of the SOE sector and on the divestiture process.
 4 II. DESCRIPTION OF PROJECT COMPONENTS A. Public Enterprise Reform Program Background 11. As of 1994, the public sector accounted for an estimated 35 percent of GDP, including 40 percent of manufacturing activity and virtually all of the financial sector and utilities. The two hundred or so enterprises remaining in public ownership had approximately 150,000 employees in 1991. Reliable estimates are not available of the values of these enterprises or of their assets. SOE liabilities to the Government exceeded US$1 billion at the end of 1994, while the Government had guaranteed SOE borrowings amounting to approximately US$250 million. 12. The role of the Government in the SOE sector is evolving. As privatization continues, the size of the sector is being reduced. The Government's role is evolving from one of relatively active involvement in the management of enterprises to a more passive role in managing a portfolio of equity investments, loans and guarantees. It is placing increased emphasis on creating an appropriate policy, legal and regulatory framework for strategic sectors. Specifically, it has developed and is implementing policy and regulatory frameworks in the financial, mining and telecommunications sectors designed to liberalize and allow private investment, and, with assistance under this project, proposes to expand these reforms into other sectors that have large SOEs, such as cocoa, petroleum, and aviation. 13. The SEC is the central government body in Ghana for monitoring and assessing the performance of the SOE sector and for providing analyses and other supporting services to reform and strengthen the performance of SOEs. Its functions are intended to be complementary to and supportive of the other main instrument for reform of this sector, namely divestiture. To give focus to divestiture, the DIC was spun off from the SEC in 1989. The operations of the SEC have been supported by IDA through the Public Enterprises Technical Assistance (PETA) project. These operations would continue to be supported under the project, alongside and in coordination with the development of a portfolio management capability in the Ministry of Finance. 14. The project would provide support to the Government's public enterprise reform program in following areas: (a) SOE portfolio management; (b) preparation of SOEs for divestiture; (c) transition to reformed legal framework for SOEs; and (d) developing policy and regulatory reform in key sectors. SOE portfolio management (US$ 4.10 million) 15. With the progressive reduction of the SOE sector through divestitures and the reformed legal framework which moves Government out of the management of SOEs, the Government will be strengthening its capacity to manage its portfolio of loans to and investments in SOEs. A key element of this capability will be to monitor financial performance and implement policies appropriate to its role as owner, creditor and guarantor. 16. The project would support the Ministry of Finance, working with the SEC, to develop a portfolio management capability. The objective would be to allow the Government to coordinate
 5 and manage the reduction of the size of the portfolio through divestiture, focus on core financial performance criteria, and address the new financial policy issues created by the privatization program. Specifically, the function would focus on: (a) maintaining complete and reliable information on the portfolio, including names and types of enterprises, form (equity, loan or guarantee) and extent of investment, restrictions associated with the investment (e.g. shareholders' agreements, covenants with financiers), and updated corporate secretarial information; (b) monitoring the financial performance of the portfolio (dividend payments, subventions, repayment of loans, annual audited accounts); (c) advising the Government on financial policy issues (e.g. required returns on investment, capital expenditure prior to privatization, dividend policy, on-lending arrangements, provision of guarantees, risk-sharing with the private sector); and (d) providing information and advice, including impact assessments, to allow the Government to decide on thefuture direction of and requirements for SOE reform. including the identification, timing and mode of future divestitures. 17. Information and Monitoring. Monitoring and assessing the performance of the SOE sector is a core function of the SEC. Under the PETA project, SEC has been able to develop an inventory and classification of SOEs, which had not existed previously; monitor and assess the performance of key SOEs through the establishment of an annual performance contract and monitoring system; and undertake policy studies on particular aspects of SOE performance. However, a number of important gaps and weaknesses remain in SEC's ability to monitor and assess the performance of the SOE sector. In particular, it is not in a position to track financial and operational trends in the sector as a whole. The coverage of the performance monitoring system is still in the process of being extended. Information on SOE performance resides in various databases in SEC, which are not integrated. These factors hamper SEC's ability to address the underlying weakness in the information it receives from the SOEs themselves. 18. The project would provide consultant, technical, and training services to (a) develop an integrated SOE database that would incorporate key financial and operational performance indicators, including performance on obligations to provide audited accounts, and meet tax, dividend, and debt obligations to the Government; (b) strengthen the operation of the performance contract system facilitated by SEC, in particular the analysis of overall sector performance and constraints (in this regard, a review would be undertaken of the performance monitoring system); and (c) strengthen accountability by providing public dissemination of information on the performance of the SOE sector, including the development of a public annual report on the performance of SOEs. The project would also support a program to publicize more widely audit reports of SOEs. 19. Policy for Future Development of the SOE Sector. The project would support the Government to undertake a review of its policy for the future development of the SOE sector. The review would address the Government's objectives; its role in the areas of policy, legal and regulatory issues; the identification, timing and mode of the privatization program; its role as lender and guarantor to SOEs; the management of SOE's during the period up to privatization; Government's role as minority shareholder, lender and guarantor in previous SOEs which have now been privatized; and the institutional arrangements needed to implement the amended policy. The project would support the implementation of the amended policy, which is expected to include the building of a portfolio management capability within the Ministry of Finance, with support from the SEC.
 6 20. Loans and Guarantees. With the transfer of increasing numbers of SOEs into private ownership, the role of the Government as lender and guarantor will diminish. It is expected that future borrowings of divested enterprises will be incurred without recourse to the Government. The current portfolio of loans and guarantees requires attention due to its size (at the end of 1994, outstanding loan balances exceeded $1 billion, while guaranteed balances amounted to $284 million) and because almost 50 percent is estimated by SEC to be non-performing. Improvement in the performance of the portfolio can yield significant improvements for Government revenues. Where SOEs are to be divested with continuing liabilities to, or guaranteed by, the Government, enforcement of rights under loan and guarantee agreements assumes greater importance. In preparing enterprises for divestiture, it will be important to quantify their indebtedness to the Government, including any arrears, and to ensure that these are appropriately dealt with either before (where a financial restructuring may be needed), or as part of, the divestiture process. 21. The Aid and Debt Management Unit (ADMU) of the Ministry of Finance is responsible for the management of both the asset and liability sides of the Government aid and debt portfolio. The asset side is represented by loans to SOEs and other enterprises. Budgetary constraints and the inability to pay competitive remuneration have made it difficult for the Government to recruit and retain the staff needed to effectively manage the portfolio. The Government has already sub-contracted to private banks the collection of small loan amounts. It is prepared to expand this involvement further to supplement the skills and resources of the ADMU. 22. In due course, it may be possible for the Government to divest its loan portfolio to commercial lenders. This would yield revenue (especially where the on-lending terms are commercial and the original donor financing terms are concessional) and contribute to the development of local capital markets. It would also place the enterprises on a more commercial arms-length relationship with lenders and level the playing field between commercial enterprises with access to Government funding and those without. 23. The project would support the appointment of consultants to assist the ADMU to design and implement improved information systems on the loan and guarantee portfolio. It would also support the appointment of private financial institutions, with remuneration linked to performance, to supplement the capacity of the ADMU to manage the portfolio. Preparation of SOEs for Divestiture (US$ 0.3 7 million) 24. An acceleration and expansion of the divestiture program lies at the core of the Government's efforts to establish a climate conducive to private investment. Under the Government's accelerated divestiture program, 110 small and medium-sized SOEs placed on the divestiture list will be divested, of which at least 48 are to be completed by March, 1997. In addition, the Government intends to offer for sale at least three large non-bank SOEs, including Ghana Telecom, by that time. The program thereafter has not been defined in detail, but at the intended pace, the bulk of the current SOE sector would be divested over the next five years or so. To enable this program to be defined and implemented, upstream preparatory work of enterprises for divestiture has been undertaken under the auspices of the SEC, largely on a contract basis.
 7 25. The roles of DIC and SEC in pre-divestiture work have been clarified. In particular, it has been agreed that in order to avoid duplication of work and gain maximum effectiveness from the pre-divestiture work of SEC, DIC will carefully define the nature of the documentation and preparatory work to be done by SEC before enterprises are "handed over" to DIC for divestiture. SEC will make available its information at hand-over, and thereafter any additional pre- divestiture work will be done by or at the request of DIC. SEC would continue, in collaboration with DIC, to monitor the performance of SOEs up to the point of actual divestiture. 26. The project would provide consultant and technical services to prepare the extension of the divestiture program. It would help the SEC to (a) prepare company profiles and identify issues to be addressed for the remainder of the SOEs to be divested; (b) recommend necessary actions to be taken prior to divestiture of enterprises. including where necessary clearing of accounting arrears, title issues, and environmental and regulatory matters; and (c) identify and address policy issues related to the extension of the program and the preparation of enterprises for divestiture. Transition to Reformed Legal Framework for SOEs (US$ 0.35 million) 27. The operational and financial performance of SOEs to date remains decidedly mixed. A number of enterprises that have not been placed on the divestiture list have been deemed non- viable, and are receiving subventions. Others are imposing costs on the economy, impeding development. The SEC does not have authority to directly supervise enterprises. However, it has undertaken several initiatives designed to improve the framework for improved SOE performance and assist in that process. These include the Conversion to Companies Act (Act 461) of 1993, under which SOEs are to operate under reformed governance structures under the Companies Code. Assisting in the implementation of this framework for SOEs will be an important focus of SEC activity in the coming years. In addition, SEC envisages assisting SOEs in adapting their corporate strategies to the new environment, and organizational restructuring advice as tools to improve sector performance. 28. The conversion of the legal form of SOEs to limited liability companies holds out the potential for achieving significant imiprovemenlt in SOE performance. However, for these benefits to be realized, implementation of the reformed framework needs to go beyond a change in legal form to encompass effective autonomy from government interference in day to day managemiient and the exposure of the SOE to market competition. It is through the operation of improved incentives for performiance that results will be realized. These incentives would be applied through the clearer accountability to the shareholder embodied in the new framework. The framework also permits greater financial autonomy to SOEs through the ability to independently tap private debt and equity markets. 29. The project would provide selective support to these efforts. In particular, it would provide technical and consultant services to SEC to (a) assist SOEs in implementing Act 461 by providing training and assistance in preparing Company Regulations; and (b) develop diagnostic and action plans for subvented SOEs to facilitate their commercialization, in collaboration with the relevant sector Ministry. SOE management, and the Ministry of Finance.
 8 Developing Policy and Regulatory Reform in Key Sectors (US$ 2.23 million) 30. In a number of sectors dominated by SOEs, policy and regulatory reforms will be required to achieve significant improvements in sector performance and privatization of the enterprises. Comprehensive reform programs are already being supported by IDA operations in the financial, mining and telecommunication sectors. In three sectors, aviation, cocoa and petroleum, the Government has initiated policy and regulatory reviews with a view to implementing reform and encouraging private participation in the coming years. 31. Cocoa. Cocoa is Ghana's most important income-generating crop. However, the sector has suffered from declining output and inadequate investment, while farmers have received only one half of the proceeds of cocoa exports, the other half being used to pay taxes to the Government and to cover the costs of the Cocoa Board. The Government has been moving to liberalize the marketing of cocoa, which has been dominated by the Cocoa Board. In 1992, domestic marketing of cocoa was opened up to private traders. The Government has commissioned a study, with IDA support, to review and develop options regarding the external marketing of cocoa. 32. Petroleum. The Government has embarked on a program of liberalization and reform of the petroleum sector. The importation of oil, which had been the responsibility of Ghana National Petroleum Corporation, is being opened up to competition. Tema Oil Refinery, which is state owned, is on the list of SOEs to be privatized, as is GOIL, the state-owned oil marketing company. The Government is also developing a strategic approach to sector reform. 33. Aviation. The Government has recently taken steps to improve the performance of Ghana Airways and to prepare it for possible privatization. Previously a statutory corporation, it was converted to a limited liability company in 1995. Private sector representatives have been appointed to the board, including as chairman. Speedwing Ltd., a subsidiary of British Airways, has been appointed through a performance-related management contract to fill key management positions, including that of Chief Executive. The Government wishes this program to proceed within a strong policy and regulatory framework, and therefore intends to review existing arrangements in these areas. 34. The project would assist the Government to prepare Ghana Airways for privatization. Initially, this would involve a review of sector policy and regulatory arrangements by the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC). The project would then finance services, such as investment banking, legal and accounting, required to conclude the transaction. The project would also examine ways in which the operations of the Civil Aviation Authority could accommodate private sector participation. IDA would work closely with IFC to ensure a coordinated Bank Group approach to the sector. 35. Reform of the cocoa and petroleum sectors is the subject of dialogue between the Government and IDA in the context of the proposed PSAC II adjustment credit, which is presently under preparation. The extent of the support to be provided under the project for these reforms would be finalized once the scope of the adjustment credit has been concluded later in 1996. Pending this, the project cost estimates include a provision of US$2 million to support implementation of the reforms. Consulting services would be procured by the MOF acting in collaboration with the relevant sector ministry.
 9 36. The project would support the development of policy and regulatory reform in these three sectors sectors by financing specialist services and workshops to help the Government undertake policy review and consensus building, develop regulatory capacity, perform upstream preparation of enterprises for privatization, and direct services needed to conclude privatization transactions. Strengthening SEC Capacity (US$0.35 million) 37. Over the coming years, there will be an increasing need to put SEC into a more sustainable position. Although the scale of its activities is expected to shrink towards the end of the proposed project, as the size of the SOE sector and its urgent needs for reform are reduced, ongoing capacity will need to be further developed. The project would, in the context of integrating SEC's work with the development of portfolio management capacity within the Ministry of Finance, support the strengthening of SEC's capacity through the provision of (a) updated office equipment and (b) training of staff. With respect to the latter, the training would be based on an assessment of staff and institutional needs, and use local resources as far as possible. Provision would be made in the terms of reference of technical assistance consultants to transfer relevant skills to SEC staff in a structured fashion. B. Privatization Background 38. The Government is committed to a policy of increasing private sector participation in SOEs. The divestiture of its ownership interest is at the core of the Government's privatization program. Divestiture commenced in 1987. The DIC has statutory responsibility under PNDC law 426 of 1993 for the divestiture, involving the sale or liquidation, of all enterprises owned by the state. 39. Initial progress was slow, and the first sale was concluded in 1990. Since then the pace has increased and by the end of 1995, DIC had signed agreements with buyers or commenced liquidation of around 120 enterprises. 40. The Government decided in 1994 to accelerate the divestiture program. In April 1994, it raised around $350 million from the sale of half of its majority stake in Ashanti Goldfields Corporation and a further $23 million from the sale of its stake in seven manufacturing companies listed on the Ghana Stock Exchange. Divestiture of its controlling stakes in the other state-owned mining companies was substantially completed in 1995. In January 1995, the Government announced that it would sell a further 114 enterprises. It also approved and published new procedures for carrying out divestitures, including arrangements whereby DIC would enhance its capacity by contracting out the sale of enterprises to private firms. In late 1995 and early 1996, the Government successfully floated two state-owned banks on the Stock Exchange and advertized the sale of a strategic stake in Ghana Telecom. It intends to continue the divestiture program once the sale of the 114 enterprises announced in 1995 has been completed.
 10 41. IDA is supporting the accelerated program through a series of adjustment and technical assistance operations. As part of the First Private Sector Adjustment Credit (PSAC I) amounting to US$75 million, the credit agreement for which was signed in July 1995 (Cr. 2418-GH), the Government has committed to divesting not less than 48 small and medium-sized SOEs and to bring at least 3 strategic enterprises to the point of sale. A second adjustment operation (PSAC II) is scheduled for IDA FY97 and will address the cocoa and petroleum sectors. IDA is assisting the Government to privatize state-owned banks (Cr. 23 18-GH), non-bank financial institutions (Cr. 2792-GH), mining (Cr. 192 1-GH) and Ghana Telecom (operation under preparation) as part of wider sector reform programs. This project would continue the support provided under the PETA Project (Cr. 1847-GH) which is scheduled to close on June 30, 1996. 42. The accelerated program is making new demands on DIC. It has primary responsibility for implementing the program, focusing initially on the 114 enterprises announced by the Government in 1995, and subsequently on the remaining SOEs of which there are approximately 100. It will do so using new procedures which were approved and published by the Government in 1995. As the program is implemented, it will give greater attention to openness and public availability of information concerning the divestiture process, building and sustaining public support and investor confidence, addressing the issue of redundant labor, and providing opportunities for Ghanaian investors. The privatization of larger and more complex enterprises will require legal, policy and regulatory initiatives, requiring DIC to work closely with the relevant sector authorities. Public information and communications strategy (US$2.46 million) 43. The project would support the Government and DIC to develop and implement a public information and communications strategy designed to build and sustain public and stakeholder support and investor confidence. International and local consultants have been appointed by DIC, financed under the PETA project, to develop the strategy. The objectives of the strategy are to (a) enhance public support for the divestiture program though greater public awareness; (b) strengthen the effectiveness of the program through targeted communication with potential investors in enterprises to be divested; and (c) increase the impact of the program on private sector development through communication with the broader investor community. The strategy will provide for effective two-way communication. 44. Once the strategy is approved, it is envisaged that a firm would be engaged, with IDA support under the proposed credit, to assist in its implementation. The implementation of the strategy would be coordinated with other public information efforts of the Government related to divestiture, including periodic assessments of the impact of the program. Divestiture of SOEs (US$12.66 million) 45. DIC is focusing initially on the sale of the 114 enterprises announced by the Government in 1995. Around 100 enterprises will then remain in state ownership. The Government has confirmed that it intends to extend the program to include the bulk of the remaining SOEs, and has already commenced preparatory work on the sale of some of these enterprises. Initial work on some additional enterprises has already commenced. The resources made available under the project are based on the assumption that the program will continue. The scope of the continuing program will be defined more precisely during the mid-term review. The extent of IDA support
 11 beyond that date will be determined by the results of the review and the feasibility of the proposed revolving fund. 46. The Government approved and published new divestiture procedures in 1995 designed to make the process more effective and to make information more readily available to interested parties. DIC has prepared a comprehensive manual which sets out in detail how the new procedures will be operationalized. The manual deals with the preparation of documentation, advertising, bidding procedures, evaluation criteria and procedures, negotiation and approvals, sale and purchase documentation, and completion and post-completion matters. 47. DIC is putting in place the resources needed to implement an accelerated program by outsourcing the sale of enterprises to private firms. The procedures manual specifies the arrangements for outsourcing. A register of firms has been prepared following public advertisement internationally and within Ghana. It is intended that most future privatizations will be outsourced, at an expected annual average rate of 25 to 35 enterprises, focusing mainly on medium and large enterprises. The process of outsourcing the sale of the first 15 medium enterprises has commenced. Not less than 50 percent of the firms' remuneration will be represented by success fees to be paid from the proceeds of the sale. The proposed credit would finance the retainer fees and reimbursable expenses of the firms. As part of the mid-term review, DIC and IDA would examine whether a revolving fund could be established using a portion of the sale proceeds to finance all of the firms' remuneration. 48. The benefits of outsourcing are that it allows DIC to accelerate the pace of divestiture by utilizing private sector resources and expertise; wvith the appropriate financial and success fee incentives in place, private sector privatization specialists with hands-on experience in negotiating sale transactions are more likely in certain cases to secure quality investors and increased sales proceeds in a timely manner: openness and access to information concerning the divestiture process is enhanced; and it fosters development of the private services sector in Ghana, through direct use of local consultants, lawyers and financial advisory firms to undertake divestitures, and throughi the skills transfer arising from associations between local and international firms. 49. Participation by Ghanaian businessmen, managers. employees, institutional and individual investors. and the public at large in the divestiture program has been limited. This is partially due to the absence of a fully functioning capital market in the country. The Government has sought to facilitate local ownership through a system of deferred payments for share or asset sales. However, the system has been implemented on an ad hoc basis and problems have arisen with its administration, in particular in relation to collection of the deferred balances. The project would support the Government and DIC to identify and put in place sustainable arrangements to address this issue. Among the options which will be examined are preferential ownership plans for employees, Employee Share Option Plans, arrangements for management buy-outs, structuring sales of assets or shares in smaller lots to facilitate interest by smaller investors, the use of the Privatization Trust to be established under the Non-Bank Financial Institutions Project, and facilitating local institutional investors. 50. A series of indicators have been identified to measure performance on the divestiture program. These include numbers of enterprises divested (analyzed by small medium and large, and by mode of divestiture); number of divestitures out-sourced; net proceeds on divestiture;
 12 level of deferred payments and arrears arising under deferred payments (individual and aggregate); and average time taken to divest enterprises. Supportfor Labor Redundancies (US$7.14 million) 51. Enterprises have three forms of non-wage liabilities in respect of their employees - termination/severance benefits, end-of-service benefits (ESBs), and social security contributions. Termination benefits are payable when through internal reorganization or change in economic conditions specific classes of workers are no longer required, while severance payments are payable when the company is wound up or a new ownership arrangement results in dismissal of members of the work force. The provisions for termination and severance payments are by convention set out in collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) negotiated between the trade union and the enterprise. ESBs (lump sum retirement or termination benefits payable to retiring workers in lieu of pension) were discontinued in 1991 and all obligations of the Govemment have since been paid or provided for. Social security payments are payable to the Social Security and National Insurance Trust at a rate of 12.5 percent by all employers, public and private. They are generally up to date, but in some cases there are arrears. 52. Labor issues in recent divestitures have been handled on an ad hoc basis. The entitlements of junior employees are normally recorded in CBAs. Senior employees and management have negotiated similar or more generous agreements, but their standing appears less certain as the agreements are not recognized as CBAs and have effectively been negotiated by senior employees with themselves. While there is no explicit policy and there is some inconsistency in application from enterprise to enterprise, a general pattern has emerged. It shows that payments for junior staff will be in the range of 6 to 15 months, with most in the range of 8 to 10 months, of salary, generally irrespective of the length of service. Similar payments have been made in respect of senior staff, although more generous provisions had sometimes been negotiated. Profitable enterprises pay somewhat higher severance packages than weaker ones, although ability to pay is generally not a factor in negotiating CBAs. Where workers suffer no break of employment, they are not entitled to severance payments. Most payments are ultimately agreed to by the Government rather than management, and these payments are often less than the level negotiated in the CBA. While there have been cases of unions initiating court action, both sides have generally preferred to negotiate a solution. There have been many exceptions to the above general picture however and some recent cases have shown that costs to the Government are increasing. 53. There is no reliable estimate of the potential liability for severance and termination payments arising from the divestiture program. Rough estimates are that up to 40,000 employees may be affected, at a cost of around US$ 40 million. This compares to over 60,000 redundancies from the civil service reform program and around 100,000 in the Cocoa Board in the late 1980s and early 1990s. 54. There is evidence that the behavior of both management and workers changes once the intention to privatize an enterprise is announced. There is therefore a need to take immediate action, even before the sale process commences, in such areas as forbidding the renegotiation of existing CBAs without the Government's approval, instituting a complete freeze on recruitment, ensuring that all social security payments are up to date, identifying the potential level redundancies, and preparing the labor input to the divestiture strategy.
 13 55. Despite these difficulties, and the delays which they have caused in the divestiture program, the Government has been sensitive to the issue and has generally succeeded in negotiating down CBA terms to levels which have been accepted by workers and do not generally appear excessive. Discussions with a sample of purchasers do not report any ongoing labor problems. There is also some evidence of success stories, with post-employment levels in some enterprises increasing despite initial redundancies, and wage levels also increasing. 56. The project would support the Government's efforts to manage labor redundancies caused by the divestiture program. The objectives are to ensure that investors are offered a "clean slate" enterprise with all outstanding liabilities to employees resolved or properly provisioned for; the negotiation of equitable, legally defensible and affordable packages for those employees adversely affected by restructuring and divestiture; maintenance of good industrial relations throughout the process; and provision of retraining packages for staff made redundant. 57. Specifically the project would support (a) a participatory review of the Government's policy for dealing with labor redundancies; (b) the preparation of an estimate of the potential number of employees to be made redundant and the associated costs; (c) arrangements to communicate the policy to the public and workers, including at the level of each enterprise; (d) putting in place an appropriate institutional framework and the implementation of an action program to implement the revised policy; (e) an assessment of the impact of the program on workers; and (f) measures to mitigate the potential extent of the problem, such as facilitating where possible the early re-hire of workers by the in-coming buyer, the introduction of voluntary redundancy packages for all SOEs, the introduction of training and redeployment support schemes (building on the experience gained with the civil service and Cocoa Board) and the introduction of a standard workforce communications checklist. 58. The European Development Fund (EDF) would provide funds in support of re-training and redeployment of redundant workers. IDA would support the policy review, institutional arrangements, communications, training, and other impact mitigation measures. Strengthening DIC capacity (US$ 5.43 million) 59. Notwithstanding the decision to increase the participation of private firms in the divestiture transaction process through outsourcing, the scale of DIC's activities will increase. It will have additional responsibility for managing and monitoring a comprehensive outsourcing program and will be required to do so in a timely manner. It will retain its current responsibility for the development and implementation of the overall divestiture program by continuing to review and decide upon all divestiture transactions and by being involved directly in some of the smaller divestiture transactions, albeit on a reduced scale. Finally, it will be responsible for the implementation of an expanded communcations strategy, improved financial and operational information systems, and assisting with the implementation of the labor redundancy program. DIC is expected to be disbanded when the program is complete. 60. The ODA is presently making US$2.6 million equivalent available through to the end of 1997 to support four full-time advisers in DIC with specialist expertise in privatization, as well as short-term consulting support and office equipment. It will consider extending its assistance
 14 at that time. DIC will appoint counterpart staff on a contract basis for each of these positions. DIC's operating costs will be financed by budgetary support and a portion of the proceeds from sales. 61. Comprehensive performance indicators have been identified and the systems designed will allow actual performance against these targets to be measured. The project would provide support to DIC to implement these systems. Independent external auditors acceptable to IDA would be appointed to audit DIC's accounts, including the Divestiture Account. The audited accounts would be published. C. Program Coordination 62. Several agencies are involved in the reform and privatization of SOEs. The DIC, reporting to the Office of the President, has statutory responsibility for the sale of all SOEs approved for divestiture. Sector ministries, SEC, and a number of regulatory and other agencies have various responsibilities with respect to SOEs. Shares in SOEs which have been converted to limited liability companies are vested in the Minister of Finance, who also is responsible for all financial policy issues, as well as the large portfolio of govemment loans and guarantees to the sector. The reform and privatization program affects many other stakeholders, including private investors, workers, creditors, and customers. 63. The scale and complexity of the reform program has increased. The Government approved in 1995 an accelerated divestiture program and new divestiture procedures. The privatization of strategic enterprises necessarily involves an upstream examination of, and possible changes to, the legal, policy and regulatory environment. Good progress has been made on the liberalization and privatization of the mining, banking, and telecommunications sectors. Reforms are also planned in the aviation, cocoa, petroleum, infrastructure, and non-banking financial sectors. IDA is supporting reforms in most of these sectors through a mix of adjustment, investment and technical assistance operations. The need to build and sustain public support and investor confidence, address the issue of redunidant workers, and promote opportunties for local investors has added to the complexity of the program. 64. The Govemment intends to strengthen its capacity to implement the program and to improve coordination among all the agencies involved. It has established a Project Coordination Unit (PCU) and appointed a Project Coordinator within the Ministry of Finance. The PCU would also administer the project. The project would provide support to the PCU amounting to US$1.18 million in the areas of training, consulting services to address and advise on policy issues and assist with implementation, and operating costs. doc.repnme: Ghana - Public Enterprise and Privatization Technical Assistance Project
doc.abstracts: The objective of the Public Enterprise and Privatization Technical Assistance Project is to assist the government of Ghana to implement its public enterprise reform and privatization program. The project will consist of the following two components: (A) a public enterprise reform program, which will focus on: 1) preparing enterprises for divestiture; 2) monitoring the performance of enterprises, and making information available to the government and the public; 3) a review of government policy for the public enterprise sector, with an increased focus on the management of the government's portfolio of equity investments, loans and guarantees; 4) policy and regulatory reform in a number of key sectors in which state-owned enterprises (SOEs) are dominant - aviation, cocoa and petroleum; and 5) building capacity within the Ministry of Finance and State Enterprises Commission (SEC); and (B) a privatization program, which will focus on: 1) acceleration of the divestiture program using newly-approved procedures; 2) contracting out the sale of enterprises to private firms; 3) arrangements to address labor redundancies caused by divestiture; 4) arrangements to promote the participation of Ghanaians in the investment opportunities created by divestiture; 5) implementation of a public information and communications strategy, including periodic impact assessments with the participation of key stakeholders; and 6) building capacity within the Divestiture Implementation Committee (DIC).
